_meta.notes: assignedScore is the manually assigned 0-100 score; bucket/thumb are sentiment markers

reviews.pullQuote: Intelligent, disciplined, and often absorbing—but rarely electrifying. Coon anchors the production with a performance of formidable control and emotional clarity.
A riveting Carrie Coon cuts to the bone in Tracy Letts' excellent, itchy paranoid fantasia.
The sensationally unnerving Broadway premiere of Bug reads like an origin story for our climate of mistrust and isolation.
Amid crafty scenic metamorphoses, blood, violence, and pyrotechnics, the show's most special effects are performances by Coon and Smallwood.
Bug is a peculiar play that has aged well in our conspiracy-obsessed culture. It's an admirably combustible work that gets the job done.
It wants to make you scream and maybe chuckle to yourself about it, though its most disturbing suggestion is that the descent into conspiratorial thinking might feel a little like falling in love.
It's a genuine treat to watch Carrie Coon walk on the seedy side on Broadway in the wild but sometimes wobbly Bug.
The slipperiness of ostensible skepticism into utter credulity is what makes Bug continue to resonate so powerfully today.
Manic, disturbing and relentless, Bug gets under the audience's skin and remains there long after the final curtain drops.
To really do its work, Bug needs to get under our skin, and here it never quite does. We've got to feel not only the ick but the itch.
Coon and Smallwood's performances navigating this nightmare slalom are electric. The play, prophetically prescient as it may be, is not.
Carrie Coon spirals into shocking places in this revival of Tracy Letts' paranoid thriller.
On-brand Steppenwolf acting, typified by go-for-broke intensity, naked in more ways than one, from Coon and Smallwood.
Raw, go-for-broke, go-for-everything acting that exemplifies the Steppenwolf aesthetic. By the end, Smallwood and Coon are a match made in hell.
The stillness is deafening, as is the quiet desperation that lives inside this woman's body.
Bug was a shot of adrenaline and a delayed-release dose of anxiety when seen Off-Broadway, but much of the effect for me has worn off.
The disturbing play still manages to burrow its way into your brain and is likely to haunt your dreams for nights afterwards.
In 1996, Bug was a warning. In 2026, it's a mirror. This is not a feel-good night at the theater. It's raw, violent, sexy, and deeply American.
Carrie Coon delivers a powerful performance as a working-class woman stuck in a dingy Oklahoma motel room.
There could have been a better time to bring back Bug, Tracy Letts's disturbing drama about paranoia and its devastating consequences.
Harrison has a dream collaborator in Kauffman, who is a master at creating emotion without hitting an audience over the head.
Squibb merits attention with a remarkable performance that combines frostiness and fogginess into a firm coat of rime.
Harrison is a formidable craftsman and Marjorie Prime is built very well, but in a way it resembles one of its own artificial humans.
June Squibb, miraculously still treading the boards at age 96, is the marquee draw, proving once again that she's become a national treasure.
The play is far more disquieting, merely as a consequence of the passage of time. I can't ever remember seeing a play whose impact felt so utterly different a decade later.
At its core, Marjorie Prime tells a simple kitchen-sink story of two adults trying to care for an aging relative.
Still relevant after its world premiere at Playwrights Horizons, the 90-minute chamber drama sparkles and unsettles in its Broadway debut.
June Squibb brings a lovable feistiness to the role of Marjorie. Danny Burstein delivers another remarkable performance.
Director Anne Kauffman has assembled an A-list ensemble that hums like a finely tuned machine.
Cynthia Nixon gives an all-too-real performance of a woman who masks her psychological pain with well-read intelligence.
Compelling, witty, and wrenching.
The new production struck me as having been revised, not necessarily for the better. Yet it turns out that the script is exactly the same.
Marjorie Prime ages into something unsettling on Broadway.
June Squibb is a marvel in an early highlight of the Broadway season.
June Squibb and a superb company turn Marjorie Prime into an acting masterclass about mortality, memory, and why we love.
Jordan Harrison's thought-provoking drama gets an exquisitely acted Broadway run at Second Stage's Hayes Theater.
People without people's problems, humor or original insights—which is to say, hardly human at all.
The musical version has been made with so much love and sincerity it survives with most of its heart intact.
If The Outsiders sometimes traffics in cliche, it makes up for it with the tenderness and muscle of its songs, staging, and performances.
Deep into the new musical The Outsiders, there is a sequence that is rawer and more pulse-pounding than anything else on Broadway right now.
The Outsiders musical takes a milder approach, peering under the hood of masculinity to the tune and pace of indie emo.
The show has great visual touches but falters when the characters open their mouths. It overexplains everything, all the time.
The show loses its narrative thread in a second act where the requisite narrative tension dissipates instead of intensifying.
The rumble perversely transforms this coming-of-age story about brotherhood into an Abercrombie & Fitch photoshoot.
The '60s-set classic makes for a solid, if unspectacular, Broadway musical.
The Outsiders often feels like a musical that wants to hang with the grown-ups while unable to leave behind its adolescent earnestness.
S.E. Hinton's beloved novel transforms into glittering Broadway musical.
Not since Beetlejuice or Newsies-mania have I felt the energy of young audience members rallying around a musical. Perhaps the best new musical of this decade.
The S.E. Hinton classic gets the Broadway treatment courtesy of a gang of talented young guns. An emotionally and viscerally satisfying work.
A perfectly respectable effort with many laudable elements. What it mostly seems to lack is a reason for being.
The Outsiders boasts terrific performances and imaginative staging. You'll want to be inside the Jacobs Theatre to see it.
Under the fluent direction of Danya Taymor, the young cast is sensational, engulfing the theater with emotional heat.
The Outsiders sparkles not just as a smart adaptation but a genuinely great American musical.
Says the show feels simple and honest and that Tutty and Pitts are perfectly equipped to carry this delightful musical.
Calls it an enchanting new musical classic, a crush note to New York and one of the best new musicals of the year.
Raves about Tutty's star-making turn and the show's many laughs, noting Robin as a grounded counterweight.
Says the show charms in Act One but hits turbulence in Act Two and should have been a tighter 90 minutes.
Credits the show for balancing rom-com cliches with sharp left turns and nuanced commentary about connection.
Singles out Tutty as a dazzling newcomer with appealing looks, pure voice, and strong comic instincts.
Focuses on how much fun the evening is thanks to the score, witty lyrics, and lead performances.
Calls it an effervescent, charmingly simple new musical comedy that delivers classic rom-com laughter, escape, and fantasy.
Says the show avoids treacle thanks to a banter-filled book and twinkling contemporary score with stirring emotion and humor.
Describes the show as modest and appealing but warns that audience euphoria could create misleading expectations.
Says the Broadway recipe needs more time in the oven and suggests seeing a great cake slice instead of the show.
Finds the show funny and occasionally moving but a little off-feeling, saved by the charm of the leads.
Critic feels generational whiplash and argues the show misunderstands Gen Z while older audiences around him adore it.
Says the show soon runs out of positions for its two-hander leads and spins its wheels with novelty numbers.
Says the piece comes alive when it leans into wistful, specific feelings rather than the love story.
Finds the meet-cute promising but thinks the rom-com premise turns problematic, especially in the second act.
David Adjmi's astonishing new play delivers far more than a dishy glimpse inside the recording studio during rock's golden age.
A work of theatrical virtuosity that is brave, purposeful, and rich. Solid Theatrical Gold.
Funny, raw and poignant in equal measure. Its searing emotional heft creeps up and grabs you by the throat. It's a chart topper.
A stunning feat of scoring. In its bones, it's a love song, bittersweet and wounded and ferociously loyal, to the act of making art.
Daniel Aukin's superb production navigates the change to Broadway without missing a beat. A richly satisfying multitrack production.
A brilliant 'Behind the Music' play on Broadway. A hypernaturalistic meditation on the thrill, and also the danger, of collaborating on art.
A true Broadway masterpiece. The performances are so exquisitely rendered, so beautifully lived-in, that every moment is full.
One of the most original, stunningly designed, and technically dazzling plays in New York. A must-experience, rather than simply a must-see.
A brilliant piece of must-see Broadway. Masterful, Chekhovian. An object lesson in the importance of detail and veracity.
A riveting, painful, funny, intense, toe-tapping journey. The end result can best be described as solid gold.
One of the very best plays to open last year Off Broadway and now this season on Broadway. Like a lost Robert Altman film.
Not only do the actors nail the acting, they make for a very credible hit-making band, playing their own instruments and singing their own songs.
A hyperrealistic triumph. You won't see more assured direction this year. The scenes create a haunting cycle of tension and release.
A cast in perfect harmony and every note intact. David Adjmi and Will Butler's studio-set play moves to Broadway brilliantly.
David Adjmi's astounding new work, itself near-perfect, captures the wondrous highs and excruciating lows of the creative process. You'll want to live in this play forever.
Despite its lengthy four acts, the play puts forth catchy songs and star-making performances. The payoff is fantastic.
The laughter comes more frequently than it did Off Broadway. Newfound admiration for the musicianship on display.
More than three hours of predictable events. The characters are stereotypical band members with stereotypical lives.
Hell's Kitchen has earned its place on Broadway: The revised show is thrilling from beginning to end, and easily stands out as one of the rare must-sees in a crowded season.
Playwright Kristoffer Diaz, director Michael Greif, and choreographer Camille A. Brown have found the right recipe for this show and cooked up a heck of a block party.
A sparkling story paying homage to New York, to that beautiful and heartbreaking transition between girlhood and womanhood and to the women who hold our hands through it all.
Moon is a great discovery, a virtuoso who also appears surprised and delighted by her own talent. If only the material written for her could be as distinctive.
Keys' hit songs weave an evocative and lively tapestry of 1990s New York City, and these phenomenal actors knock you over with her tunes. A show that's true to its city.
Hell's Kitchen has wonderful new and old tunes and a talented cast, but only a sliver of a very safe story that tries to seem more consequential than it is.
What emerges is a reminder of Keys' marvelous songwriting talent via her soulful, soaring R&B hits and Moon's ability to bring down the house with song after song.
What is so remarkable about Hell's Kitchen is that a story so familiar can also somehow feel so fresh. Right from the outset, both the neighborhood and stage come alive.
Since Hell's Kitchen doesn't have much of a story to tell, Diaz pumps up the drama in a couple of ways that ultimately feel false.
There are no surprises in the mother-daughter narrative, but you get Keys' songs and zesty choreography in the story of a teenager growing up in a New York neighborhood.
The secret sauce of this entertainment package is choreographer Camille A. Brown. Brown's work ranks among the very best of this Broadway season.
In Hell's Kitchen, they've crafted a perfectly nice musical out of the soul-fired songbook of Alicia Keys.
Solidly energetic and completely electric. Grammy-winning Alicia Keys elevates the genre high above the standard fare of jukebox musicals.
PHENOMENAL. It is thrilling. It is entertaining. It has probably the best music currently on Broadway, sung by a top-notch cast of talented performers.
If there are reasons to be skeptical about an Alicia Keys jukebox musical, all are banished the second its cast starts singing. One of the most freshly sung productions in memory.
There isn't a moment on Broadway this season that is more powerful than Kecia Lewis singing 'Perfect Way to Die' in Hell's Kitchen.
A supersmart musical about making a connection arrives on Broadway in a joyful, heartbreaking, cutting-edge production.
The fact that this show is casting its firefly glow on Broadway at all feels like a gift.
An undeniably moving, well-made, adorable musical that teaches us how to be human.
Maybe Happy Ending exudes an undeniable charm and warmth. A refreshingly original, poignant celebration of finding connections.
Darren Criss and Helen J Shen delight in this utterly enchanting robot romance.
Downright peaceful, as well as charming and beautiful and poignant. Michael Arden knows how and when to hold back.
Darren Criss and Helen J. Shen shine in this robotic romance.
Undoubtedly the most original musical to grace Broadway since Kimberly Akimbo.
Maybe Happy Ending is surely the balm for audiences tired of loud Broadway shows.
A very special show; a tender, visionary ode to the space we're able to create and hold for feeling.
MJ is trying to have it both ways. It wants to blame everything sad and weird about Jackson on others but credit him alone for his every good deed and success.
The authorized biomusical MJ wants very much to freeze Michael Jackson in 1992. It is a deftly crafted jukebox nostalgia trip.
In answer to the question of whether it's possible to separate the art from the artist, MJ performs a slick, crotch-grabbing sidestep.
MJ, like its subject, is captivating and hard to shake. The musical takes audiences through Jackson's life and catalog with impressive ease.
The creative team's painstaking work has resulted in a riveting, adrenaline rush of a show, propelled by remarkable dancing and a mesmerizing central performance by Myles Frost.
An altogether baffling musical about Michael Jackson. A sloppy yet very calculated piece of image branding.
It's not a smooth musical. The troubles are much bigger than the controversy surrounding its subject.
MJ pushes hard and unceasingly to move beyond the just-good-enough nostalgia that can turn even second-rate jukebox productions into crowd pleasers. It succeeds: MJ is a wildly entertaining marvel.
When lead actor Myles Frost enters as MJ, he is greeted by the audience as if he really is Michael Jackson reincarnated.
We hear of his being demanding during rehearsals, that he's 'going through a lot,' that he had a tough life, but none of this is explored in any meaningful way.
MJ is very smooth, somewhat criminal. A dance musical of the first rank that is genuinely beautiful to experience throughout.
The darker elements of 'The Great Gatsby' prove more elusive, which blunts the impact overall.
Jeremy Jordan makes a dashing Jay Gatsby. He successfully differentiates himself from his predecessors, finding a softer dialect and leaning into Gatsby's humorous nervousness.
Under Marc Bruni's jazz-hands-happy direction, this Gatsby feels like it belongs on a cruise or in a theme park.
The Great Gatsby looks great. If you want production values, this adaptation delivers more than any other new musical of the overstuffed Broadway season.
The production splashes in excess, but of the Las Vegas residency kind. The 'nouveau riche' mansion isn't as opulent or lush as one might imagine.
This revisionary attempt to turn 'The Great Gatsby' into a clown car of passionate entanglements skids off the road when calamity is meant to strike.
An ambitious, flashy, but ill-conceived adaptation. Jordan and Noblezada are simply sensational, but the production prioritizes glitter over depth.
This might not be a Great Gatsby that English teachers will agree with, but if you're going to drop $200 on a Broadway ticket, it certainly gives you your money's worth.
We never really understand what this new musical is trying to say. Beyond exploiting this famously beguiling title, it's never clear what this telling really wants to say.
Don't misunderstand me: The Great Gatsby is not a smart, tasteful musical that can't compete with tackier ones. It simply fails to be tacky enough.
The new musical about Jay Gatsby and Daisy Buchanan lays a big egg. What Gatsby should definitely not ever do is lead a chorus of tap dancers.
A mess, turning a beloved novel about class, morality, and exploding gender norms into a glossy Jazz Age love story with all the subtlety of a canary-yellow Rolls Royce.
A great, big Broadway extravaganza that explodes with life and energy. Gatsby's Tony-nominated leads, Jordan and Noblezada, revel in the whimsical naivety and rampant toxicity.
A great big Broadway extravaganza that may dazzle viewers at first but, much like the green light, perfection remains close, yet just out of reach.
A musical about the Jazz Age with almost no jazz? A man of mystery who tells us everything in his first song?
SIX totally rules! A rollicking, reverberant blast from the past with inexhaustibly catchy songs.
The production is triumphant. The thing feels intimate, private-jokey, for-the-squad.
There's much to admire and love. It may not be Masterpiece Theater, but this 'Six' is a solid '10' for joy.
The zingy Broadway musical Six celebrates, in boisterous fashion, the union of English dynastic history and modern pop music.
Six is probably closer to a three, but it's entertaining enough as bubbly pop confections go.
With the curtain finally rising on 'Six,' the Broadway season not only got a charge — it got supercharged.
The songs here, by Toby Marlow and Lucy Moss, are all whip-smart and catchy. 'Six' is one of the few original musicals in memory whose score is radio-ready.
Six is still so freaking fun. Toby Marlow and Lucy Moss's Edinburgh Fringe Festival hit turned international addiction has the veneer of a glittering pop confection.
The terrific new musical Six has lost none of its vitality and charm over the ensuing months of darkness.
A needed antidote to 'Anastasia,' 'Frozen,' 'Jagged Little Pill,' 'Wicked' and other pompous shows of female empowerment.
Pure musical theatre elation for a pop-packed 75 minutes. You'll laugh. You'll cry. You'll dance.
A glossy, well-engineered Fringe stunt made good. The six actresses are tremendous talents.
A rafter-raising entertainment. It has mass appeal, immediacy, enthusiasm, and an incredibly high sense of style.
Unlike 'Hamilton,' where hip hop culture is placed into service on behalf of history; in 'Six,' history is placed into service on behalf of pop culture.
Of course it's worth the wait. One of the cleverest, wittiest, flashiest musicals in town.
While there is every reason to be skeptical of a Shakespearean jukebox musical, '& Juliet' makes it work remarkably well. It's the most fun you'll have in a Broadway theater right now.
So shoot me: I liked it. It felt so wrong; it felt so right. Jukebox musicals may still be bottom feeders, but, as '& Juliet' proves, there are sometimes small treasures to be found in the murk.
& Juliet barely takes time to define its heroine; it puts her at the center of the story and then makes her its least interesting character.
If you were to adapt the feeling of getting day-drunk on cheap rosé for the stage, you'd get & Juliet.
It's strictly for kicks — breezy and campy, with some fine voices and even better dancing.
It's not that & Juliet is unenjoyable – it isn't. Somewhere beneath the bombast and repetition is a sweet(ish) and smart(ish) tale.
There's something a little relentless about & Juliet's dogged eagerness to entertain, but nakedly joyful too.
Enter '& Juliet,' a savvy if stunningly unsubtle mashup of a musical from London that aims to redress that balance for Broadway fun and profit.
'& Juliet' is quite the most excruciating experience I've had on Broadway in decades.
The musical gives new life to a classic tragedy. A slim but cheeky and eager-to-entertain jukebox musical bursting with chart-toppers.
Max Martin's music is unstoppable. Lorna Courtney is a ferociously voiced Juliet.
Luke Sheppard's direction effectively showcases many of the more appealing quirks in Read's characters. Unfortunately, that sticky morass claims many more victims in Act 2.
This effort featuring dozens of earworm-heavy smash hits provides the sort of infectious silliness that makes for a very enjoyable evening.
The Bard takes a back seat to the Backstreet Boys and Britney Spears in '& Juliet,' a jukebox musical sung by a cast with glorious pop voices.
Is it electrifying? God, yes. The results are slick, sleek, mordant. It's a spine tingler.
Mark Strong and Lesley Manville shine in Robert Icke's version of the complex Greek tragedy. Icke's Oedipus is continuously engaging and smart.
The taut spin on Oedipus is a rare and magnificent feat of adaptation: Robert Icke draws Sophocles' ancient play into the present.
Manville and Strong crackle together — their chemistry is steamy and genuine.
Icke's work is really something: I can't recall ever being as riveted at a Greek tragedy.
It's an effective, affecting and strictly naturalistic new interpretation of this canonical drama.
Pulse-pounding and thrilling! Mark Strong and Lesley Manville are ferocious in a pulse-pounding Broadway tragedy.
Mark Strong and Lesley Manville are giving two of this year's great performances.
A gasp-inducing tale of truth and lies that sets the stage on fire.
Lesley Manville and Mark Strong have disturbingly good chemistry as theater's most famous twice-related couple.
Strong exposes the boyish vulnerability within the sophisticated politician in his sympathetically beguiling portrayal.
Manville's speech is one of the most compelling moments in Robert Icke's contemporary reworking of Sophocles' play.
Laser-sharp performances, led by the phenomenal pairing of Mark Strong and Lesley Manville. But Icke has hit a wall with this particular staging.
Robert Icke's massively intoxicating, Olivier Award-winning adaptation.
Mark Strong and Lesley Manville are explosive in this reimagined classic.
Sometimes a show isn't bad. It is downright despicable. Christopher Wheeldon's flashy choreography tarts up Nottage's radically misinformed book.
MJ is far more unconventional — and far more complicated — than previous bio-musicals. Thrilling and confounding.
MJ sets the platinum standard the often uninspired, generic jukebox musical could benefit to emulate.
There are some three dozen songs presented in 135 minutes, with exciting choreography by director Christopher Wheeldon built on Jackson's signature moves.
Forget East Egg and West Egg. The creators of the new musical 'The Great Gatsby' have laid an egg.
I felt the warmth in The Great Gatsby, but it was begging to bring on the heat.
This is modern day American musical theatre at its finest, that feels right for the whole family.
Six truly is the top ticket to celebrate the return of the live stage show. If you're up for a euphoric celebration of the musical medium, Six is queen of the castle.
Six is as well-suited to this moment as any piece of live entertainment.
There is not a single flaw in this production's casting. The six women reveal more about womanhood, modern stardom, and survival than a musical with this logline has any right to.
The key to enjoying yourself at '& Juliet' is to ignore the plot entirely and pretend you're at a concert. It is an empty-headed good time.
& Juliet is a joy ride from start to finish. Lorna Courtney's vocals rival those of most of her songs' original artists.
Characters feel cartoonish. Juliet is given a big go-girl liberation narrative, with the slight problem that she never seems that oppressed in the first place.
More parody than tragedy. The biggest pleasure is watching how Icke pastes modern references onto a classic story. It's often fun to watch, but never more than clever.
Strong and Manville give performances of remarkable intensity. However, Icke's effort to remake Sophocles' tragedy into a modern-day political fable largely didn't work for me.

Is it possible to make a show about a man whose memory dwells under deep shadow? Of course it is. But you do then have to make a good show. MJ is a Frankenstein's monster constantly tugging apologetically at its forelock.
The 'Thriller' number is a carnival of MJ's psychological demons – the toll of perfectionism and the ghosts of bad ideologies – and brought the house down.
The show is genuinely beautiful to experience throughout, which one almost never can say about jukebox musicals.
For all its surface flash and stylish presentation, 'MJ' comes across as superficial fan-bait: a glossy but unrevelatory moonwalk through the ups and downs of Jackson's career.
Two and a half hours of glittery hagiography.
MJ neither defends its subject from the most serious charges against him nor urges us to distinguish between the artist and his art. It's at its most winning when song and dance are in progress.
We are relaxed by the exercise of laughing for 75 minutes in our beleaguered world.
'The Outsiders' is very much an outsider itself driven by authenticity, earnestness, youth and ample heart.
Achieves its best musical moments by serving up several still, quiet and understated tunes.
By act two, the show felt like a mechanical procession of plot progression and teen melodrama.
Still has the power to inspire an entire generation of young theatergoers.
The show loses its narrative thread in a second act where the requisite narrative tension dissipates.
Despite picture-perfect staging and a passionate cast of triple threats, 'The Outsiders' coasts only on Golden-Age appeals.
Beyond exploiting this famously beguiling title, it's never clear what this telling really wants to say.
On the surface, it's alluring, but it's nothing more than a modish echo of an over-romanticized time period.
Theatergoers will find much to delight in.
The ferocious, feminist, and fun new Broadway musical about the six wives of Henry VIII gives these ladies a very refreshing 2021 update.
Whether it is satisfying as a piece of theater is a dicier proposition.
If The First Shadow is purely an act of fan service, at least it's an unapologetic and satisfying one.
Padding a skeleton doesn't make it scarier, just bulkier.
An exorbitant spectacle wrapped around the scrappy, gushy heart of the original.
This production doesn't just change the game of Broadway, it smashes the game board and shoots it into a new dimension.
An absolute must-see for all enthusiasts.
Immersive, heartfelt, and exhilarating.
An assault on the senses.
A three-hour fan wiki brought to life, complete with stilted dialogue.
Resembles a jukebox musical comedy with shock effects haphazardly thrown in.
Astonishing simply for its scale, and never boring.
Technically impressive but soporific.
Special effects abundant but not as overwhelming as expected.
A thrill ride not to be forgotten.
Far from a hack job or mere brand exploitation.
A non-stop thrill ride.
A candy-colored glitter bomb of a show.
Allow Juliet to reintroduce herself.
Delivers both her spoken and musical material with complete assurance.
A sumptuous, hypnotic and somewhat hyperactive musical.
Go to hell. And by hell, of course, I mean Hadestown, a fizzy, moody, thrilling new Broadway musical.
The exhilarating opening number of the utterly fabulous Hadestown.
A perfectly heavenly musical.
The most thrilling new original musical of the season.
A gorgeous, shattering piece of musical storytelling.
A breathtaking achievement in musical theater.
A captivating journey to the underworld.
This Moulin Rouge is a cloud-surfing, natural high of a production.
The show is A LOT...both intoxicating and exhausting in its unrelenting visual and sonic assault.
Let's revel in what Broadway actually can do for a beloved musical property: bring it to life.
Most, though, remember to turn the damn spigot off.
Not unlike earlier botched attempts at bringing visually distinct movie musicals to the stage.
A gaudy and gorgeous jukebox pastiche that virtually defies you not to be entertained.
A smart, shameless and extravagantly entertaining production.
A spectacle of sensory overload that celebrates love, beauty, truth, and freedom.
A newborn, old-fashioned, pleasure-giving musical has arrived... feast upon its sweetness.
Surpasses both Tony winners... Broadway hasn't seen anything like it since Mel Brooks.
The first Broadway musical from the South Park team will have the comedy faithful flocking.
A shrewd, remarkably well-crafted and wholly hilarious new Broadway musical.
Tuneful, unabashedly silly and absolutely uproarious new musical.
Hard to imagine anyone topping the ding-dong hilarity set off by the missionaries.
You've discovered your true calling — as the wit-spewing class clowns of Broadway.
This new version remains ravishingly entertaining. Three and a half hours of enchantment is still a hell of a ride.
Despite its shrinking, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child has kept most of its charm.
The magical stagecraft continues to dazzle.
A theatrical experience unlike any other.
The spectacular set pieces remain dazzling.
Still a magical theatrical experience.
The indelibly exuberant jukebox musical returns with all its feel-good energy intact.
There are no lame numbers, no filler; the show is all high points, which is why it generates a kind of wall-to-wall karaoke ecstasy.
The flaws – and they are not inconsiderable – remain. Catherine Johnson's book is as hokey and stitched-together as ever.
The talented actresses sail away with this Broadway production so entirely, you won't be wanting for the screen stars.
This new production can be described in two words: severely cheapened.
This is not a dark Brechtian take on a well-known musical—but I'm not sure anyone needs that from Mamma Mia!
A fine iteration that certainly is sprightlier than the last time I saw the show.
Wicked does not, alas, speak hopefully for the future of the Broadway musical.
A strenuous effort to be all things to all people tends to weigh down this lumbering, overstuffed production.
Such a Wicked waste of talent.
An overproduced, overblown, confusingly dark and laboriously ambitious jumble.
The show's twenty-two songs were written by Stephen Schwartz, and not one of them is memorable.
Flat, heavy, long, and boring — all of which apply to the show.
The most complete, and completely satisfying, new musical I've come across in a long time.
A spectacle worth seeing for its visual grandeur and Chenoweth's performance.
Yes, it really is that good. Hamilton might just about be worth mortgaging your house for.
There has been nothing on Broadway in the past 20 years to rival the riveting, exhilarating and haunting Hamilton.
They used up all the damn words. What is left to say?
The best and most important Broadway musical of the past decade. Do whatever you have to do short of grand larceny to score a ticket.
Hamilton brings something new to the musical theatre, and does it so very compellingly that superlatives are in order.
A watershed moment for musical theater.
A show of staggering ambition and achievement.
A revolution in American musical theater.
Suddenly, you're 4 years old again, and you've been taken to the circus for the first time.
Julie Taymor's staging is a marvel, a theatrical achievement unrivaled in its beauty, brains and ingenuity.
A stunning theatrical event that transforms the animated film into something far more magical.
A visual feast that exceeds all expectations.
Disney has created a new standard for theatrical spectacle.
Playful and warm, funny and exciting, The Lion King will enchant children and adults in equal measure.
These performers know just how to take off the chill. Make love to the audience was another Fosse dictum. That's exactly what they do.
The spirit of Fosse's genius never leaves the stage. Chicago will dazzle newcomers to the trademark Fosse dance style.
This Chicago impressed me far more than the original.
The priceless Bebe Neuwirth leads a femme chorus through a darkly hilarious recitation.
A stripped-down production that proves less is more.
Bebe Neuwirth and Ann Reinking deliver star-making performances.
Aladdin defied my dour expectations. It has an infectious and only mildly syrupy spirit.
The magic-carpet ride is magical. But the notion that it resurrects the spirit of Howard Ashman is a joke.
The carpet flies, kids, and it's awesome. An enjoyable throwback to old-time musical comedy.
James Monroe Iglehart all but erases the memory of Robin Williams. A career-defining performance.
A big comedy musical perfect for anyone looking for light-hearted fun.
While it doesn't rival The Lion King, the show's ebullient comic spirit should make it a popular hit.
Iglehart's Genie is a hopped-up cross between Fats Waller and Cab Calloway.
The emotions are deeply aligned and easily shared by the audience.
Vibrantly exciting new musical.
High end jukebox musical but lacking substantive narrative.
Magnificent and destined for the record books.

I enjoyed it well enough, but would have enjoyed it much more if the jokes landed harder. Whether 'Operation Mincemeat' works as well will depend a lot on your answer to that question: But is it funny?

Operation Mincemeat isn't exactly blazingly clever—the jokes fly thick and fast, and they tend toward broad grin-crackers rather than breathless zingers—but it overflows with good humor and heartfelt commitment.
Though the main characters are played for laughs, each one, amid all the comic chaos, also reveals their own dignity, heart, and humanity.
Jak Malone provides show's meatiest dramatic moment in the 'Dear Bill' ballad.
This plucky musical provides jubilant escapism in generous doses.
For those who complain about jukebox shows and movie adaptations on Broadway, Operation Mincemeat is a must-see show.
An often tiring wallop of frenetic hyperactivity. The Red Bull tweeness gets grating.
The frenzied direction forced someone behind me to whisper halfway through Act 1, 'This is exhausting.' Nothing kills a laugh faster than seeing actors sweat.
Contemporary and self-aware with sly critiques of British ruling class.
The five performers could pass for Swiss clock figures; their ensemble presentation is like nothing—or very few things—seen on a local stage before. Gleeful obligatory viewing.
Malone's rendition of 'Dear Bill' likely nabs awards; the emotional grounding elevates the extended silliness.
Operation Mincemeat is totally lovable and expertly zany, with Big Let's Put on a Show Energy.
British comedy captures hagiographic, self-deprecating, ironic, tragic elements.
A zany, high-energy crowd-pleaser with five actors juggling 87 characters and an unexpected poignancy.
A real beating heart elevates the show above farce with emotional depth.
Secretly full of heart; unafraid to slam audience with emotional wallop. There's nothing else like it on Broadway.
A quirky British import that has long surpassed its humble beginnings and become a classic big, brassy Broadway experience.
Mincemeat is supremely entertaining. The ensemble is indefatigable, the stagecraft is inventive and the slapstick sublime.
The five-person cast's ability to do quick costume changes and switch genders and characters on a dime are truly medal-worthy.
A genre-busting celebration of musical storytelling that bursts with both hilarity and heart.
Terribly clever and frightfully British, with a strong next-generation Monty Python vibe. 'Dear Bill' is the song that brings the story home.
The most original and innovative show on New York's main theatrical drag this autumn—and it dazzles with subtlety rather than bombast.
A darling gem of a show with a big heart and a captivating sideways sensibility. A refreshing model of innovation.
Director Michael Arden's gorgeous staging makes the most of the sets and videos. No maybe about it — Maybe Happy Ending has theatrical magic.
Maybe the musical takes a few too many tries to reach its (maybe) happy ending. But this is a show bursting with genuine feeling.
Dazzles with its love story and astounds with its visual accomplishments. There's nothing robotic about this production.
Exudes an undeniable charm and warmth...a poignant celebration of human connection.
Manifested in ways that even Stephen Sondheim could not have dreamed.
The most original and enchanting new musical to arrive on Broadway in years.
This is a show pulling on the threads that make Disney's capital so everlasting.
The spotlighting of small things amid the noise and chaos of one of the biggest cities in the world makes Hell's Kitchen such a delight.
